0.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
0.text: We are here for the second Presidential Debate, a town hall sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. The Gallup organization chose 82 uncommitted voters from the New York area. Their questions will drive the night. My goal is to give the conversation direction and to ensure questions get answered.
0.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

1.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
1.text: The questions are known to me and my team only. Neither the commission, nor the candidates have seen them. I hope to get to as many questions as possible, and because I am the optimistic sort, I'm sure the candidates will oblige by keeping their answers concise and on point.
1.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

2.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
2.text: Each candidate has as much as 2 minutes to respond to a common question, and there will be a 2-minute follow-up. The audience here in the hall has agreed to be polite and attentive; no cheering, no booing, or outbursts of any sort.
2.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

3.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
3.text: We will set aside that agreement just this once to welcome President Barack Obama and Governor Mitt Romney.
3.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

4.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
4.text: Gentlemen, thank you both for joining us here tonight. We have a lot of folks who have been waiting all day to talk to you, so I want to get right to it.
4.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

5.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
5.text: Governor Romney, as you know, you won the coin toss, so the first question will go to you. And I want to turn to a first-time voter, Jeremy Epstein, who has a question for you.
5.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

6.speaker: Education/College Affordability/Job Creation and Growth
6.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

7.speaker: Q.
7.text: Mr. President, Governor Romney, as a 20-year-old college student, all I hear from professors, neighbors, and others is that when I graduate, I'll have little chance to get employment. What can you say to reassure me, but more importantly, my parents, that I will be able to sufficiently support myself after I graduate?
7.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

8.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
8.text: Thank you, Jeremy. I appreciate your question. And thank you for being here this evening. And to all of those from Nassau County here that have come, thank you for your time. Thank you to Hofstra University and to Candy Crowley for organizing and leading this event.
8.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

9.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
9.text: Thank you, Mr. President, also for being part of this debate.
9.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

10.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
10.text: Your question is one that's being asked by college kids all over this country. I was in Pennsylvania with someone who had just graduated. This was in Philadelphia, and she said: "I've got my degree, I can't find a job. I've got three part-time jobs; they're just barely enough to pay for my food and pay for an apartment. I can't begin to pay back my student loans."
10.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

11.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
11.text: So what we have to do is two things. We have to make sure that we make it easier for kids to afford college and also make sure that when they get out of college there's a job. When I was Governor of Massachusetts, to get a high school degree you had to pass an exam. If you graduated in the top quarter of your class, we gave you a John and Abigail Adams Scholarship: 4 years tuition free to the college of your choice in Massachusetts; it's a public institution.
11.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

12.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
12.text: I want to make sure we keep our Pell grant program growing. We're also going to have our loan program so that people are able to afford school. But the key thing is to make sure you can get a job when you get out of school. And what's happened over the last 4 years has been very, very hard for America's young people.
12.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

13.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
13.text: I want you to be able to get a job. I know what it takes to get this economy going. With half of college kids graduating this year without a college—excuse me—without a job and without a college-level job, that's just unacceptable. And likewise, you got more and more debt on your back. So more debt and less jobs. I'm going to change that. I know what it takes to create good jobs again. I know what it takes to make sure that you have the kind of opportunity you deserve.
13.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

14.speaker: Republican Presidential Nominee W. Mitt Romney.
14.text: And kids across this country are going to recognize we're bringing back an economy. It's not going to be like the last 4 years. The middle class has been crushed over the last 4 years, and jobs have been too scarce. I know what it takes to bring them back, and I'm going to do that and make sure when you graduate—when do you graduate?
14.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

15.speaker: Q.
15.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

16.speaker: Gov. Romney.
16.text: 2014. When you come out in 2014, I presume I'm going to be President; I'm going to make sure you get a job. Thanks, Jeremy.
16.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

17.speaker: Q.
17.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

18.speaker: Gov. Romney.
18.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

19.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
19.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

20.speaker: Job Creation and Growth/Education/Domestic Energy Sources/Deficit and National Debt
20.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

21.speaker: The President.
21.text: Jeremy, first of all, your future is bright. And the fact that you're making an investment in higher education is critical not just to you, but to the entire Nation. Now, the most important thing we can do is to make sure that we are creating jobs in this country, but not just jobs, good-paying jobs, ones that can support a family.
21.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

22.speaker: The President.
22.text: And what I want to do is build on the 5 million jobs that we've created over the last 30 months in the private sector alone. And there are a bunch of things that we can do to make sure your future is bright.
22.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

23.speaker: The President.
23.text: Number one: I want to build manufacturing jobs in this country again. When Governor Romney said we should let Detroit go bankrupt, I said, we're going to bet on American workers and the American auto industry, and it's come surging back. I want to do that in industries not just in Detroit, but all across the country. And that means we change our Tax Code so we're giving incentives to companies that are investing here in the United States and creating jobs here. It also means we're helping them and small businesses to export all around the world to new markets.
23.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

24.speaker: The President.
24.text: Number two: We've got to make sure that we have the best education system in the world. And the fact that you're going to college is great, but I want everybody to get a great education. And we've worked hard to make sure that student loans are available for folks like you. But I also want to make sure that community colleges are offering slots for workers to get retrained for the jobs that are out there right now and the jobs of the future.
24.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

25.speaker: The President.
25.text: Number three: We've got to control our own energy. Not only oil and natural gas, which we've been investing in, but also we've got to make sure we're building the energy sources of the future, not just thinking about next year, but 10 years from now, 20 years from now. That's why we've invested in solar and wind and biofuels, energy-efficient cars.
25.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

26.speaker: The President.
26.text: We've got to reduce our deficit, but we've got to do it in a balanced way, asking the wealthy to pay a little bit more along with cuts so that we can invest in education like yours. And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America: roads, bridges, schools. We do those things, not only is your future going to be bright, but America's future is going to be bright as well.
26.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

27.speaker: Job Losses/Job Creation and Growth/Automobile Industry
27.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

28.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
28.text: Let me ask you for a more immediate answer, beginning with Mr. Romney. Just quickly, what can you do? We're looking at a situation where 40 percent of the unemployed have been unemployed for 6 months or more. They don't have the 2 years that Jeremy has. What about those long-term unemployed who need a job right now?
28.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

29.speaker: Gov. Romney.
29.text: Well, what you're seeing in this country is 23 million people struggling to find a job and a lot of them, as you say, Candy, have been out of work for a long, long, long time. The President's policies have been exercised over the last 4 years, and they haven't put Americans back to work. We have fewer people working today than we had when the President took office. If the—the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent when he took office; it's 7.8 percent now. But if you calculated that unemployment rate taking back the people who dropped out of the workforce, it would be 10.7 percent.
29.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

30.speaker: Gov. Romney.
30.text: We have not made the progress we need to make to put people back to work. That's why I put out a five-point plan that gets America 12 million new jobs in 4 years and rising take-home pay. It's going to help Jeremy get a job when he comes out of school. It's going to help people across the country that are unemployed right now.
30.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

31.speaker: Gov. Romney.
31.text: And one thing that the President said, which I want to make sure that we understand: He said that I said we should take Detroit bankrupt. And that's right. My plan was to have the company go through bankruptcy like 7-Eleven did and Macy's and Continental Airlines and come out stronger. And I know he keeps saying, you wanted to take Detroit bankrupt. Well, the President took Detroit bankrupt. You took General Motors bankrupt. You took Chrysler bankrupt. So when you say that I wanted to take the auto industry bankrupt, you actually did.
31.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

32.speaker: Gov. Romney.
32.text: And I think it's important to know that that was a process that was necessary to get those companies back on their feet so they could start hiring more people. That was precisely what I recommended and ultimately what happened.
32.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

33.speaker: Automobile Industry/Governor Romney's Economic Platform
33.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

34.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
34.text: Let me give the President a chance. Go ahead.
34.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

35.speaker: The President.
35.text: Candy, what Governor Romney said just isn't true. He wanted to take them into bankruptcy without providing them any way to stay open, and we would have lost a million jobs. And that—don't take my word for it. Take the executives at GM and Chrysler, some of whom are Republicans, may even support Governor Romney, but they'll tell you his prescription wasn't going to work.
35.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

36.speaker: The President.
36.text: And Governor Romney says he's got a five-point plan. Governor Romney doesn't have a five-point plan; he has a one-point plan. And that plan is to make sure that folks at the top play by a different set of rules. That's been his philosophy in the private sector. That's been his philosophy as Governor. That's been his philosophy as a Presidential candidate. You can make a lot of money and pay lower tax rates than somebody who makes a lot less. You can ship jobs overseas and get tax breaks for it. You can invest in a company, bankrupt it, lay off the workers, strip away their pensions, and you still make money.
36.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

37.speaker: The President.
37.text: That's exactly the philosophy that we've seen in place for the last decade. That's what's been squeezing middle class families. And we have fought back for 4 years to get out of that mess. The last thing we need to do is to go back to the very same policies that got us there.
37.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

38.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
38.text: Mr. President, the next question is going to be for you here. And Mr. Romney—Governor Romney, there'll be plenty of chances here to go on, but I want to——
38.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

39.speaker: Gov. Romney.
39.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

40.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
40.text: ——we have all these folks—I will let you absolutely——
40.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

41.speaker: Gov. Romney.
41.text: ——that Detroit answer and the rest of the answer, way off the mark.
41.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

42.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
42.text: Okay. We'll—you certainly will have lots of time here coming up, because I want to move you on to something that's sort of connected to cars here and go over—and we want to get a question from Phillip Tricolla.
42.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

43.speaker: Domestic Energy Sources/Alternative Energy Sources
43.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

44.speaker: Q.
44.text: Your Energy Secretary, Steven Chu, has now been on record three times stating it's not policy of his Department to help lower gas prices. Do you agree with Secretary Chu that this is not the job of the Energy Department?
44.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

45.speaker: The President.
45.text: The most important thing we can do is to make sure we control our own energy. So here's what I've done since I've been President. We have increased oil production to the highest levels in 16 years. Natural gas production is the highest it's been in decades. We have seen increases in coal production and coal employment.
45.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

46.speaker: The President.
46.text: But what I've also said is we can't just produce traditional sources of energy. We've also got to look to the future. That's why we doubled fuel efficiency standards on cars. That means that in the middle of the next decade, any car you buy, you're going to end up going twice as far on a gallon of gas. That's why we've doubled clean energy production like wind and solar and biofuels.
46.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

47.speaker: The President.
47.text: And all these things have contributed to us lowering our oil imports to the lowest levels in 16 years. Now, I want to build on that. And that means, yes, we still continue to open up new areas for drilling. We continue to make it a priority for us to go after natural gas. We've got potentially 600,000 jobs and a hundred years' worth of energy right beneath our feet with natural gas. And we can do it in an environmentally sound way.
47.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

48.speaker: The President.
48.text: But we've also got to continue to figure out how we have efficient energy, because ultimately, that's how we're going to reduce demand and that's what's going to keep gas prices lower.
48.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

49.speaker: The President.
49.text: Now, Governor Romney will say he's got an all-of-the-above plan. But basically, his plan is to let the oil companies write the energy policies. So he's got the oil and gas part, but he doesn't have the clean energy part.
49.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

50.speaker: The President.
50.text: And if we're only thinking about tomorrow or the next day, and not thinking about 10 years from now, we're not going to control our own economic future. Because China, Germany, they're making these investments. And I'm not going to cede those jobs of the future to those countries. I expect those new energy sources to be built right here in the United States. That's going to help Jeremy get a job. It's also going to make sure that you're not paying as much for gas.
50.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

51.speaker: Oil and Gas Production on Public Land/Domestic Energy Sources
51.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

52.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
52.text: Governor, on the subject of gas prices?
52.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

53.speaker: Gov. Romney.
53.text: Well, let's look at the President's policies, all right, as opposed to the rhetoric, because we've had 4 years of policies being played out. And the President's right in terms of the additional oil production, but none of it came on Federal land.
53.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

54.speaker: Gov. Romney.
54.text: As a matter of fact, oil production is down 14 percent this year on Federal land, and gas production is down 9 percent. Why? Because the President cut in half the number of licenses and permits for drilling on Federal lands and in Federal waters. So where did the increase come from? Well, a lot of it came from the Bakken range in North Dakota. What was his participation there? The administration brought a criminal action against the people drilling up there for oil, this massive new resource we have. And what was the cause? Twenty or 25 birds were killed, and they brought out a Migratory Bird Act to go after them on a criminal basis.
54.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

55.speaker: Gov. Romney.
55.text: Look, I want to make sure we use our oil, our coal, our gas, our nuclear, our renewables. I believe very much in our renewable capabilities; ethanol, wind, solar will be an important part of our energy mix. But what we don't need is to have the President keeping us from taking advantage of oil, coal, and gas. This has not been Mr. Oil or Mr. Gas or Mr. Coal. Talk to the people that are working in those industries.
55.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

56.speaker: Gov. Romney.
56.text: I was in coal country. People grab my arms and say, please save my job. The head of the EPA said you can't build a coal plant. He'll virtually—it's virtually impossible given our regulations. When the President ran for office, he said, if you build a coal plant, you can go ahead, but you'll go bankrupt. That's not the right course for America. Let's take advantage of the energy resources we have as well as the energy sources for the future. And if we do that, if we do what I'm planning on doing, which is getting us energy independent—North America energy independence within 8 years—you're going to see manufacturing jobs come back, because our energy is low cost. They're already beginning to come back, because of our abundant energy.
56.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

57.speaker: Gov. Romney.
57.text: I'll get America and North America energy independent. I'll do it by more drilling, more permits and licenses. We're going to bring that pipeline in from Canada. How in the world the President said no to that pipeline I will never know. This is about bringing good jobs back for the middle class of America, and that's what I'm going to do.
57.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

58.speaker: Oil and Gas Production on Public Land/Domestic Energy Sources
58.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

59.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
59.text: Mr. President, let me just see if I can move you to the gist of this question, which is, are we looking at the new normal? I can tell you that tomorrow morning a lot of people in Hempstead will wake up and fill up and they will find that the price of gas is over $4 a gallon. Is it within the purview of the Government to bring those prices down, or are we looking at the new normal?
59.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

60.speaker: The President.
60.text: Candy, there's no doubt that world demand has gone up. But our production is going up. And we're using oil more efficiently. And very little of what Governor Romney just said is true.
60.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

61.speaker: The President.
61.text: We've opened up public lands. We're actually drilling more on public lands than in the previous administration, and my—the previous President was an oil man. And natural gas isn't just appearing magically; we're encouraging it and working with the industry.
61.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

62.speaker: The President.
62.text: And when I hear Governor Romney say he's a big coal guy, I mean, keep in mind, when—Governor, when you were Governor of Massachusetts, you stood in front of a coal plant and pointed at it and said, "This plant kills," and took great pride in shutting it down. And now suddenly, you're a big champion of coal.
62.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

63.speaker: The President.
63.text: So what I've tried to do is be consistent. With respect to something like coal, we made the largest investment in clean coal technology to make sure that even as we're producing more coal, we're producing it cleaner and smarter. Same thing with oil. Same thing with natural gas.
63.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

64.speaker: The President.
64.text: And the proof is our oil imports are down to the lowest levels in 20 years. Oil production is up, natural gas production is up, and most importantly, we're also starting to build cars that are more efficient. And that's creating jobs. That means those cars can be exported because that's the demand around the world, and it also means that it will save money in your pocketbook. That's the strategy you need, an all-of-the-above strategy, and that's what we're going to do in the next 4 years.
64.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

65.speaker: Oil and Gas Production on Public Land/Gasoline Prices
65.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

66.speaker: Gov. Romney.
66.text: But that's not what you've done in the last 4 years. That's the problem.
66.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

67.speaker: The President.
67.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

68.speaker: Mr. Romney.
68.text: In the last 4 years, you cut permits and licenses on Federal land and Federal waters in half.
68.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

69.speaker: The President.
69.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

70.speaker: Gov. Romney.
70.text: So how much did you cut it by?
70.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

71.speaker: The President.
71.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

72.speaker: Gov. Romney.
72.text: By how much did you cut them by then?
72.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

73.speaker: The President.
73.text: Governor, we have actually produced more oil on——
73.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

74.speaker: Gov. Romney.
74.text: No, no, how much did you cut licenses and permits——
74.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

75.speaker: The President.
75.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

76.speaker: Gov. Romney.
76.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

77.speaker: The President.
77.text: Governor Romney, here's what we did: There were a whole bunch of oil companies——
77.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

78.speaker: Gov. Romney.
78.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

79.speaker: The President.
79.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

80.speaker: Gov. Romney.
80.text: ——and the question was how much did you cut them by? How much did you cut them by?
80.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

81.speaker: The President.
81.text: You want me to answer a question. I'm happy to answer the question.
81.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

82.speaker: Gov. Romney.
82.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

83.speaker: The President.
83.text: Here's what happened: You had a whole bunch of oil companies who had leases on public lands that they weren't using. So what we said was, you can't just sit on this for 10, 20, 30 years, decide when you want to drill, when you want to produce, when it's most profitable for you. These are public lands, so if you want to drill on public lands, you use it or you lose it.
83.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

84.speaker: Gov. Romney.
84.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

85.speaker: The President.
85.text: And so what we did was take away those leases, and we are now reletting them so that we can actually make a profit.
85.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

86.speaker: Gov. Romney.
86.text: And production on private—on Government lands——
86.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

87.speaker: The President.
87.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

88.speaker: Gov. Romney.
88.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

89.speaker: The President.
89.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

90.speaker: Gov. Romney.
90.text: Production on Government land of oil is down 14 percent——
90.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

91.speaker: The President.
91.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

92.speaker: Gov. Romney.
92.text: ——and production of gas is down 9 percent.
92.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

93.speaker: The President.
93.text: ——what you're saying is just not true. It's just not true.
93.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

94.speaker: Gov. Romney.
94.text: It's absolutely true. Look, there's no question but that the people recognize that we have not produced more oil and gas——
94.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

95.speaker: The President.
95.text: I'll give you your time. Go ahead.
95.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

96.speaker: Gov. Romney.
96.text: ——on Federal lands and in Federal waters. And coal? Coal production is not up; coal jobs are not up. I was just at a coal facility where some 1,200 people lost their jobs.
96.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

97.speaker: Gov. Romney.
97.text: The right course for America is to have a true all-of-the-above policy. I don't think anyone really believes that you're a person who's going to be pushing for oil and gas and coal. You'll get your chance in a moment. I'm still speaking.
97.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

98.speaker: The President.
98.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

99.speaker: Gov. Romney.
99.text: And the answer is, I don't believe people think that's the case because I——
99.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

100.speaker: The President.
100.text: ——if you're asking me a question, I'm going to answer it.
100.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

101.speaker: Gov. Romney.
101.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

102.speaker: The President.
102.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

103.speaker: Gov. Romney.
103.text: That was a statement. I don't think the American people believe that. I will fight for oil, coal, and natural gas. And the proof of whether a strategy is working or not is what the price is that you're paying at the pump. If you're paying less than you paid a year or 2 ago, why, then, the strategy is working. But you're paying more.
103.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

104.speaker: Gov. Romney.
104.text: When the President took office, the price of gasoline here in Nassau County was about a buck-eighty-six a gallon. Now it's 4 bucks a gallon. The price of electricity is up. If the President's energy policies are working, you're going to see the cost of energy come down.
104.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

105.speaker: Gov. Romney.
105.text: I will fight to create more energy in this country to get America energy secure, and part of that is bringing in a pipeline of oil from Canada, taking advantage of the oil and coal we have here, drilling offshore in Alaska, drilling offshore in Virginia, where the people want it.
105.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

106.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
106.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

107.speaker: Gov. Romney.
107.text: Those things will get us the energy we need.
107.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

108.speaker: Gasoline Prices/Oil and Gas Production/Alternative Energy Sources
108.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

109.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
109.text: Mr. President, could you address—because we did finally get to gas prices here—could you address what the Governor said, which is if your energy policy was working, the price of gasoline would not be $4 a gallon here. Is that true?
109.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

110.speaker: The President.
110.text: Well, think about what the Governor just said. He said, when I took office the price of gasoline was $1.80, $1.86. Why is that? Because the economy was on the verge of collapse. Because we were about to go through the worst recession since the Great Depression, as a consequence of some of the same policies that Governor Romney is now promoting.
110.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

111.speaker: Laughter
111.text: So it's conceivable that Governor Romney could bring down gas prices, because with his policies we might be back in that same mess. [
111.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

112.speaker: Laughter
112.text: What I want to do is to create an economy that is strong and at the same time produce energy. And with respect to this pipeline that Governor Romney keeps on talking about—we've built enough pipeline to wrap around the entire Earth once. So I'm all for pipelines. I'm all for oil production. What I'm not for is us ignoring the other half of the equation.
112.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

113.speaker: Laughter
113.text: So, for example, on wind energy, when Governor Romney says these are imaginary jobs, when you've got thousands of people right now in Iowa, right now in Colorado, who are working, creating wind power with good-paying manufacturing jobs, and the Republican Senator in that—in Iowa is all for it, providing tax credits to help this work. And Governor Romney says, I'm opposed, I'd get rid of it.
113.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

114.speaker: Laughter
114.text: That's not an energy strategy for the future. And we need to win that future.
114.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

115.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
115.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

116.speaker: The President.
116.text: And I intend to win it as President of the United States.
116.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

117.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
117.text: I got to move you along.
117.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

118.speaker: Gov. Romney.
118.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

119.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
119.text: And the next question is for you.
119.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

120.speaker: Gov. Romney.
120.text: He actually got the first question, so I get the last question—last answer on that one.
120.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

121.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
121.text: Actually, in the follow-up it doesn't quite work like that. [
121.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

122.speaker: Gov. Romney.
122.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

123.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
123.text: But I'm going to give you a chance here. I promise you, I'm going to. And the next question is for you, so if you want to continue on. But I don't want to leave all these guys sitting here, so——
123.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

124.speaker: Gov. Romney.
124.text: Candy, I don't have a policy of stopping wind jobs in Iowa. And they're not phantom jobs, they're real jobs.
124.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

125.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
125.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

126.speaker: Gov. Romney.
126.text: I appreciate wind jobs in Iowa and across our country. I appreciate the jobs in coal and oil and gas. I'm going to make sure——
126.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

127.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
127.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

128.speaker: Gov. Romney.
128.text: ——that taking advantage of our energy resources will bring back manufacturing to America. We're going to get through a very aggressive energy policy—3½ million more jobs in this country. It's critical to our future.
128.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

129.speaker: The President.
129.text: Candy, it's okay, I'm used to being interrupted.
129.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

130.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
130.text: We're going to move you along to taxes.
130.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

131.speaker: The President.
131.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

132.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
132.text: All right, we're going to move you both along to taxes over here and all these folks that have been waiting. Governor, this question is for you. It comes from Mary Polono—Polano, sorry.
132.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

133.speaker: Gov. Romney.
133.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

134.speaker: Tax Rates and Deductions
134.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

135.speaker: Q.
135.text: Governor Romney, you have stated that if you're elected President you would plan to reduce the tax rates for all the tax brackets and that you would work with the Congress to eliminate some deductions in order to make up for the loss in revenue. Concerning these various deductions—the mortgage deduction, the charitable deductions, the child tax credit, and also the—oh, what's that other credit? [
135.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

136.speaker: The President.
136.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

137.speaker: Q.
137.text: Oh, I remember—the education credits, which are important to me because I have children in college. What would be your position on those things, which are important to the middle class?
137.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

138.speaker: Gov. Romney.
138.text: Thank you very much. And let me tell you, you're absolutely right about part of that, which is I want to bring the rates down. I want to simplify the Tax Code, and I want to get middle income taxpayers to have lower taxes. And the reason I want middle income taxpayers to have lower taxes is because middle income taxpayers have been buried over the past 4 years.
138.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

139.speaker: Gov. Romney.
139.text: You've seen, as middle income people in this country, incomes go down $4,300 a family, even as gasoline prices have gone up $2,000. Health insurance premiums up $2,500. Food prices up. Utility prices up. The middle income families in America have been crushed over the last 4 years, so I want to get some relief to middle income families. That's part one.
139.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

140.speaker: Gov. Romney.
140.text: Now, how about deductions? Because I'm going to bring rates down across the board for everybody, but I'm going to limit deductions and exemptions and credits, particularly for people at the high end, because I am not going to have people at the high end pay less than they're paying now.
140.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

141.speaker: Gov. Romney.
141.text: The top 5 percent of the taxpayers will continue to pay 60 percent of the income tax the Nation collects. So that will stay the same.
141.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

142.speaker: Gov. Romney.
142.text: Middle income people are going to get a tax break. And so in terms of bringing down deductions, one way of doing that would be to say everybody gets—I'll pick a number—$25,000 of deductions and credits, and you can decide which ones to use. Your home mortgage interest deduction, charity, child tax credit, and so forth, you can use those as part of—fill in that bucket, if you will, of deductions. But your rate comes down, and the burden also comes down on you for one more reason, and that is, every middle income taxpayer no longer will pay any tax on interest, dividends, or capital gains; no tax on your savings.
142.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

143.speaker: Gov. Romney.
143.text: That makes life a lot easier. If you're getting interest from a bank, if you're getting a statement from a mutual fund, or any other kind of investments you have, you don't have to worry about filing taxes on that because there will be no taxes for anybody making $200,000 a year and less on your interest, dividends, and capital gains.
143.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

144.speaker: Gov. Romney.
144.text: Why am I lowering taxes on the middle class? Because under the last 4 years, they've been buried, and I want to help people in the middle class. And I will not—I will not under any circumstances reduce the share that's being paid by the highest income taxpayers. And I will not under any circumstances increase taxes on the middle class.
144.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

145.speaker: Gov. Romney.
145.text: The President's spending, the President's borrowing will cause this Nation to have to raise taxes on the American people, not just at the high end. A recent study has shown that people in the middle class will see $4,000 a year higher taxes as a result of the spending and borrowing of this administration. I will not let that happen. I'll get us on track to a balanced budget, and I'm going to reduce the tax burden on middle income families. And what's that going to do? It's going to help those families, and it's going to create incentives to start growing jobs again in this country.
145.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

146.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
146.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

147.speaker: Gov. Romney.
147.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

148.speaker: Tax Rates/Governor Romney's Economic Platform
148.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

149.speaker: The President.
149.text: My philosophy on taxes has been simple, and that is, I want to give middle class families and folks who are striving to get into the middle class some relief, because they have been hit hard, over the last decade, over the last 15, over the last 20 years.
149.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

150.speaker: The President.
150.text: So 4 years ago, I stood on a stage just like this one—actually, it was a town hall—and I said, I would cut taxes for middle class families, and that's what I've done, by $3,600. I said I would cut taxes for small businesses, who are the drivers and engines of growth, and we've cut them 18 times. And I want to continue those tax cuts for middle class families and for small businesses.
150.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

151.speaker: The President.
151.text: But what I've also said is if we're serious about reducing the deficit, if this is genuinely a moral obligation to the next generation, then in addition to some tough spending cuts, we've also got to make sure that the wealthy do a little bit more.
151.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

152.speaker: The President.
152.text: So what I've said is your first $250,000 worth of income, no change. And that means 98 percent of American families, 97 percent of small businesses, they will not see a tax increase. I'm ready to sign that bill right now. The only reason it's not happening is because Governor Romney's allies in Congress have held the 98 percent hostage, because they want tax breaks for the top 2 percent.
152.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

153.speaker: The President.
153.text: But what I've also said is for above $250,000, we can go back to the tax rates we had when Bill Clinton was President. We created 23 million new jobs. That's part of what took us from deficits to surplus. It will be good for our economy, and it will be good for job creation.
153.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

154.speaker: The President.
154.text: Now, Governor Romney has a different philosophy. He was on "60 Minutes" just 2 weeks ago and he was asked, is it fair for somebody like you making $20 million a year to pay a lower tax rate than a nurse or bus driver, somebody making $50,000 a year. And he said, yes, I think that's fair. Not only that, he said, I think that's what grows the economy.
154.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

155.speaker: The President.
155.text: Well, I fundamentally disagree with that. I think what grows the economy is when you get that tax credit that we put in place for your kids going to college. I think that grows the economy. I think what grows the economy is when we make sure small businesses are getting a tax credit for hiring veterans who fought for our country. That grows our economy.
155.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

156.speaker: The President.
156.text: So we just have a different theory. And when Governor Romney stands here, after a year of campaigning, when during a Republican primary, he stood on stage and said, I'm going to give tax cuts—he didn't say tax rate cuts, he said tax cuts—to everybody, including the top 1 percent, you should believe him, because that's been his history. And that's exactly the kind of top-down economics that is not going to work if we want a strong middle class and an economy that's thriving for everybody.
156.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

157.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
157.text: Governor Romney, I'm sure you've got a reply there. [
157.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

158.speaker: Tax Rates/Job Creation and Growth
158.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

159.speaker: Gov. Romney.
159.text: You're absolutely right. You heard what I said about my tax plan. The top 5 percent will continue to pay 60 percent, as they do today. I'm not looking to cut taxes for wealthy people. I am looking to cut taxes for middle income people.
159.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

160.speaker: Gov. Romney.
160.text: And why do I want to bring rates down and at the same time lower exemptions and deductions, particularly for people at the high end? Because if you bring rates down, it makes it easier for small business to keep more of their capital and hire people. And for me, this is about jobs. I want to get America's economy going again. Fifty-four percent of America's workers work in businesses that are taxed as individuals. So when you bring those rates down, those small businesses are able to keep more money and hire more people.
160.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

161.speaker: Gov. Romney.
161.text: For me, I look at what's happened in the last 4 years and say this has been a disappointment. We can do better than this. We don't have to settle for—how many months?—43 months with unemployment above 8 percent, 23 million Americans struggling to find a good job right now. There are 3½ million more women living in poverty today than when the President took office. We don't have to live like this.
161.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

162.speaker: Gov. Romney.
162.text: We can get this economy going again. My five-point plan does it. Energy independence for North America in 5 years; opening up more trade, particularly in Latin America; cracking down on China when they cheat; getting us to a balanced budget; fixing our training programs for our workers; and, finally, championing small business.
162.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

163.speaker: Gov. Romney.
163.text: I want to help small businesses grow and thrive. I know how to make that happen. I spent my life in the private sector. I know why jobs come and why they go. And they're going now because of the policies of this administration.
163.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

164.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
164.text: Governor, let me ask the President something about what you just said. The Governor says that he is not going to allow the top 5 percent—I believe is what he said—to have a tax cut, that it will all even out, that what he wants to do is give that tax cut to the middle class. Settled?
164.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

165.speaker: Budgetary Effects of Tax Cuts
165.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

166.speaker: The President.
166.text: No, it's not settled. Look, the cost of lowering rates for everybody across the board 20 percent, along with what he also wants to do in terms of eliminating the estate tax, along what he wants to do in terms of corporate changes in the Tax Code, it costs about $5 trillion.
166.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

167.speaker: The President.
167.text: Governor Romney then also wants to spend $2 trillion on additional military programs, even though the military is not asking for them. That's $7 trillion. He also wants to continue the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. That's another trillion dollars. That's $8 trillion.
167.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

168.speaker: The President.
168.text: Now, what he says is he's going to make sure that this doesn't add to the deficit and he's going to cut middle class taxes. But when he's asked how are you going to do it, which deductions, which loopholes are you going to close, he can't tell you. The fact that he only has to pay 14 percent on his taxes when a lot of you are paying much higher, he's already taken that off the board. Capital gains are going to continue to be at a low rate, so we're not going to get money that way.
168.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

169.speaker: The President.
169.text: We haven't heard from the Governor any specifics beyond Big Bird and eliminating funding for Planned Parenthood in terms of how he pays for that.
169.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

170.speaker: The President.
170.text: Now, Governor Romney was a very successful investor. If somebody came to you, Governor, with a plan that said, here, I want to spend 7 or $8 trillion and then we're going to pay for it, but we can't tell you until maybe after the election how we're going to do it, you wouldn't have taken such a sketchy deal.
170.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

171.speaker: The President.
171.text: And neither should you, the American people, because the math doesn't add up. And what's at stake here is one of two things. Either, Candy, this blows up the deficit, because keep in mind, this is just to pay for the additional spending that he's talking about—7, $8 trillion—that's before we even get to the deficit we already have.
171.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

172.speaker: The President.
172.text: Or alternatively, it's got to be paid for not only by closing deductions for wealthy individuals—that will pay for about 4 percent reduction in tax rates—you're going to be paying for it. You'll lose some deductions. And you can't buy this sales pitch. Nobody who's looked at it that's serious actually believes it adds up.
172.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

173.speaker: Gender Discrimination/Wage Equality/Education
173.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

174.speaker: Q.
174.text: In what new ways do you intend to rectify the inequalities in the workplace, specifically regarding females making only 72 percent of what their male counterparts earn?
174.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

175.speaker: The President.
175.text: Well, Catherine, this is a great question. And I was raised by a single mom who had to put herself through school while looking after two kids. And she worked hard every day and made a lot of sacrifices to make sure we got everything we needed.
175.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

176.speaker: The President.
176.text: My grandmother, she started off as a secretary in a bank. She never got a college education even though she was smart as a whip. And she worked her way up to become a vice president at a local bank, but she hit the glass ceiling. She trained people who would end up becoming her bosses during the course of her career. She didn't complain. That's not what you did in that generation.
176.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

177.speaker: The President.
177.text: And this is one of the reasons why one of the first—the first bill I signed was something called the Lilly Ledbetter bill, and this is named after this amazing woman who had been doing the same job as a man for years, found out that she was getting paid less, and the Supreme Court said that she couldn't bring suit because she should have found out about it earlier, when she had no way of finding out about it. So we fixed that.
177.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

178.speaker: The President.
178.text: And that's an example of the kind of advocacy that we need, because women are increasingly the breadwinners in the family. This is not just a women's issue. This is a family issue; this is a middle class issue. And that's why we've got to fight for it.
178.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

179.speaker: The President.
179.text: It also means that we've got to make sure that young people like yourself are able to afford a college education. Earlier, Governor Romney talked about—he wants to make Pell grants and other education accessible for young people. Well, the truth of the matter is, is that that's exactly what we've done. We've expanded Pell grants for millions of people, including millions of young women all across the country. We did it by taking $60 billion that was going to banks and lenders as middlemen for the student loan program, and we said, let's just cut out the middleman. Let's give the money directly to students. And as a consequence, we've seen millions of young people be able to afford college, and that's going to make sure that young women are going to be able to compete in that marketplace.
179.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

180.speaker: The President.
180.text: But we've got to enforce the laws, which is what we are doing. And we've also got to make sure that in every walk of life, we do not tolerate discrimination. That's been one of the hallmarks of my administration. I'm going to continue to push on this issue for the next 4 years.
180.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

181.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
181.text: Governor Romney, pay equity for women.
181.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

182.speaker: Gender Discrimination/Wage Equality/National Economy
182.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

183.speaker: Gov. Romney.
183.text: Thank you, an important topic and one which I learned a great deal about, particularly as I was serving as Governor of my State, because I had the chance to pull together a cabinet, and all the applicants seemed to be men. And I went to my staff, and I said, how come all the people for these jobs are all men? And they said, well, these are the people that have the qualifications. And I said, well, gosh, can't we find some women that are also qualified? And so we took a concerted effort to go out and find women who had backgrounds that could be qualified to become members of our cabinet. I went to a number of women's groups and said, can you help us find folks? And they brought us whole binders full of women.
183.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

184.speaker: Gov. Romney.
184.text: I was proud of the fact that after I staffed my cabinet and my senior staff, that the University of New York in Albany did a survey of all 50 States and concluded that mine had more women in senior leadership positions than any other State in America.
184.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

185.speaker: Gov. Romney.
185.text: Now, one of the reasons I was able to get so many good women to be part of that team was because of our recruiting effort, but number two, because I recognize that if you're going to have women in the workforce, that sometimes they need to be more flexible. My chief of staff, for instance, had two kids that were still in school. She said, I can't be here until 7 or 8 o'clock at night; I need to be able to get home at 5 o'clock so I can be there for making dinner for my kids and being with them when they get home from school. So we said, fine, let's have a flexible schedule so you can have hours that work for you.
185.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

186.speaker: Gov. Romney.
186.text: We're going to have to have employers in the new economy, in the economy I'm going to bring to play, that are going to be so anxious to get good workers, they're going to be anxious to hire women.
186.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

187.speaker: Gov. Romney.
187.text: In the last 4 years, women have lost 580,000 jobs. That's the net of what's happened in the last 4 years. We're still down 580,000 jobs. I mentioned 3½ million women more now in poverty than 4 years ago.
187.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

188.speaker: Gov. Romney.
188.text: What we can do to help young women and women of all ages is to have a strong economy, so strong that employers are looking to find good employees and bringing them into their workforce and adapting to a flexible work schedule that gives women the opportunities that they would otherwise not be able to afford.
188.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

189.speaker: Gov. Romney.
189.text: This is what I've done. It's what I look forward to doing. And I know what it takes to make an economy work. And I know what a working economy looks like. And an economy with 7.8 percent unemployment is not a real strong economy. An economy that has 23 million people looking for work is not a strong economy. An economy with 50 percent of kids graduating from college that can't find a job, or a college-level job, that's not what we have to have.
189.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

190.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
190.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

191.speaker: Gov. Romney.
191.text: I'm going to help women in America get good work by getting a stronger economy and by supporting women in the workforce.
191.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

192.speaker: Wage Discrimination/Contraception and Family Planning/Women's Health Issues
192.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

193.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
193.text: Mr. President, why don't you get in on this quickly, please?
193.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

194.speaker: The President.
194.text: Catherine, I just want to point out that when Governor Romney's campaign was asked about the Lilly Ledbetter bill, whether he supported it, he said, I'll get back to you. And that's not the kind of advocacy that women need in any economy.
194.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

195.speaker: The President.
195.text: Now, there are some other issues that have a bearing on how women succeed in the workplace, for example, their health care. A major difference in this campaign is that Governor Romney feels comfortable having politicians in Washington decide the health care choices that women are making. I think that's a mistake.
195.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

196.speaker: The President.
196.text: In my health care bill, I said insurance companies need to provide contraceptive coverage to everybody who's insured, because this is not just a health issue, it's an economic issue for women. It makes a difference. This is money out of that family's pocket.
196.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

197.speaker: The President.
197.text: Governor Romney not only opposed it, he suggested that, in fact, employers should be able to make the decision as to whether or not a woman gets contraception through her insurance coverage. That's not the kind of advocacy that women need.
197.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

198.speaker: The President.
198.text: When Governor Romney says that we should eliminate funding for Planned Parenthood, there are millions of women all across the country who rely on Planned Parenthood for not just contraceptive care, they rely on it for mammograms, for cervical cancer screenings. That's a pocketbook issue for women and families all across the country, and it makes a difference in terms of how well and effectively women are able to work.
198.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

199.speaker: The President.
199.text: When we talk about child care and the credits that we're providing, that makes a difference in terms of whether they can go out there and earn a living for their family.
199.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

200.speaker: The President.
200.text: These are not just women's issues. These are family issues. These are economic issues. And one of the things that makes us grow as an economy is when everybody participates and women are getting the same, fair deal as men are.
200.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

201.speaker: Ms. Crowley
201.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

202.speaker: The President.
202.text: And I've got two daughters and I want to make sure that they have the same opportunities that anybody's sons have. That's a part of what I'm fighting for as President of the United States.
202.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

203.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
203.text: I want to move us along here to Susan Katz who has a question. And, Governor, it's for you.
203.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

204.speaker: Contraception and Family Planning/Administration of Former President George W. Bush/Energy/Trade/Federal Budget/Small Business Promotion Efforts
204.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

205.speaker: Q.
205.text: Governor Romney, I am an undecided voter because I'm disappointed with the lack of progress I've seen in the last 4 years. However, I do attribute much of America's economic and international problems to the failings and missteps of the Bush administration. Since both you and President Bush are Republicans, I fear a return to the policies of those years should you win this election. What is the biggest difference between you and George W. Bush? And how do you differentiate yourself from George W. Bush?
205.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

206.speaker: Gov. Romney.
206.text: Great. Thank you. And I appreciate that question. I just want to make sure that—I think I was supposed to get that last answer, but I want to point out that I don't believe——
206.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

207.speaker: The President.
207.text: I don't think so, Candy. I want to make sure our timekeepers are working here.
207.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

208.speaker: Gov. Romney.
208.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

209.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
209.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

210.speaker: The President.
210.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

211.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
211.text: And let me tell you that the last part, it's for the two of you to talk to one another, and it isn't quite as ordered as you think. But go ahead and use this 2 minutes any way you'd like to, the question is on the floor.
211.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

212.speaker: Gov. Romney.
212.text: I'd just note that I don't believe that bureaucrats in Washington should tell someone whether they can use contraceptives or not, and I don't believe employers should tell someone whether they could have contraceptive care or not. Every woman in America should have access to contraceptives. And the President's statement of my policy is completely and totally wrong.
212.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

213.speaker: The President.
213.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

214.speaker: Gov. Romney.
214.text: Let me come back and answer your question. President Bush and I are different people, and these are different times. And that's why my five-point plan is so different than what he would have done.
214.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

215.speaker: Gov. Romney.
215.text: I mean, for instance, we can now, by virtue of new technology, actually get all the energy we need in North America without having to go to the Arabs or the Venezuelans or anyone else. That wasn't true in his time. That's why my policy starts with a very robust policy to get all that energy in North America, become energy secure.
215.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

216.speaker: Gov. Romney.
216.text: Number two, trade: I'll crack down on China. President Bush didn't. I'm also going to dramatically expand trade in Latin America. It's been growing about 12 percent per year over a long period of time. I want to add more free trade agreements so we'll have more trade.
216.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

217.speaker: Gov. Romney.
217.text: Number three, I'm going to get us to a balanced budget. President Bush didn't. President Obama was right: He said that that was outrageous to have deficits as high as half a trillion dollars under the Bush years. He was right. But then he put in place deficits twice that size for every one of his 4 years, and his forecast for the next 4 years is more deficits almost that large. So that's the next area I'm different than President Bush.
217.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

218.speaker: Gov. Romney.
218.text: And then let's take the last one, championing small business. Our party has been focused on big business too long. I came through small business. I understand how hard it is to start a small business. That's why everything I'll do is designed to help small businesses grow and add jobs. I want to keep their taxes down, on small business. I want regulators to see their job as encouraging small enterprise, not crushing it.
218.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

219.speaker: Gov. Romney.
219.text: And the thing I find most troubling about Obamacare—well, it's a long list—but one of the things I find most troubling is that when you go out and talk to small businesses and ask them what they think about it, they tell you it keeps them from hiring more people.
219.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

220.speaker: Gov. Romney.
220.text: My priority is jobs. I know how to make that happen. And President Bush had a very different path for a very different time. My path is designed in getting small businesses to grow and hire people.
220.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

221.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
221.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

222.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
222.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

223.speaker: Job Creation and Growth/Governor Romney's Economic and Social Platforms
223.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

224.speaker: The President.
224.text: Well, first of all, I think it's important to tell you that we did come in during some tough times. We were losing 800,000 jobs a month when I started. But we have been digging our way out of policies that were misplaced and focused on the top doing very well and middle class folks not doing well. And we've seen 30 consecutive—31 consecutive months of job growth, 5.2 million new jobs created. And the plans that I talked about will create even more.
224.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

225.speaker: The President.
225.text: But when Governor Romney says that he has a very different economic plan, the centerpiece of his economic plan are tax cuts. That's what took us from surplus to deficit. When he talks about getting tough on China, keep in mind that Governor Romney invested in companies that were pioneers of outsourcing to China and is currently investing in countries—in companies that are building surveillance equipment for China to spy on its own folks.
225.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

226.speaker: The President.
226.text: That's—Governor, you're the last person who is going to get tough on China.
226.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

227.speaker: The President.
227.text: And what we've done when it comes to trade is not only sign three trade deals to open up new markets, but we've also set up a task force for trade that goes after anybody who is taking advantage of American workers or businesses and not creating a level playing field. We've brought twice as many cases against unfair trading practices than the previous administration, and we've won every single one that's been decided.
227.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

228.speaker: The President.
228.text: When I said that we had to make sure that China was not flooding our domestic market with cheap tires, Governor Romney said I was being protectionist, that it wouldn't be helpful to American workers. Well, in fact, we saved a thousand jobs. And that's the kind of tough trade actions that are required.
228.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

229.speaker: The President.
229.text: But the last point I want to make is this: There are some things where Governor Romney is different from George Bush. George Bush didn't propose turning Medicare into a voucher. George Bush embraced comprehensive immigration reform; he didn't call for self-deportation. George Bush never suggested that we eliminate funding for Planned Parenthood.
229.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

230.speaker: The President.
230.text: So there are differences between Governor Romney and George Bush, but they're not on economic policy. In some ways, he's gone to a more extreme place when it comes to social policy. And I think that's a mistake. That's not how we're going to move our economy forward.
230.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

231.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
231.text: I want to move you both along to the next question because it's in the same wheelhouse so you will be able to respond. But the President does get this question. I want to call on Michael Jones.
231.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

232.speaker: The President's Accomplishments/Governor Romney's Economic and Social Platforms
232.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

233.speaker: Q.
233.text: Mr. President, I voted for you in 2008. What have you done or accomplished to earn my vote in 2012? I'm not that optimistic as I was in 2012. Most things I need for everyday living are very expensive.
233.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

234.speaker: The President.
234.text: Well, we've gone through a tough 4 years, there's no doubt about it. But 4 years ago, I told the American people and I told you I would cut taxes for middle class families, and I did. I told you I'd cut taxes for small businesses, and I have. I said that I'd end the war in Iraq, and I did. I said we'd refocus attention on those who actually attacked us on 9/11, and we have gone after Al Qaida's leadership like never before, and Usama bin Laden is dead.
234.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

235.speaker: The President.
235.text: I said that we would put in place health care reform to make sure that insurance companies can't jerk you around and if you don't have health insurance, that you'd have a chance to get affordable insurance, and I have.
235.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

236.speaker: The President.
236.text: I committed that I would rein in the excesses of Wall Street, and we passed the toughest Wall Street reforms since the 1930s.
236.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

237.speaker: The President.
237.text: We've created 5 million jobs—gone from 800,000 jobs a month being lost—and we are making progress. We saved an auto industry that was on the brink of collapse.
237.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

238.speaker: The President.
238.text: Now, does that mean you're not struggling? Absolutely not. A lot of us are. And that's why the plan that I've put forward for manufacturing and education and reducing our deficit in a sensible way, using the savings from ending wars to rebuild America and putting people back to work, making sure that we are controlling our own energy, but not just the energy of today, but also the energy of the future—all those things will make a difference.
238.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

239.speaker: The President.
239.text: So the point is the commitments I've made I've kept. And those that I haven't been able to keep, it's not for lack of trying, and we're going to get it done in a second term. But you should pay attention to this campaign, because Governor Romney has made some commitments as well, and I suspect he'll keep those too. When Members of the Republican Congress say, we're going to sign a no-tax pledge so that we don't ask a dime from millionaires and billionaires to reduce our deficit so we can still invest in education and helping kids go to college, he said, me too.
239.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

240.speaker: The President.
240.text: When they said, we're going to cut Planned Parenthood funding, he said, me too. When they said, we're going to repeal Obamacare—the first thing I'm going to do, despite the fact that it's the same health care plan that he passed in Massachusetts and is working well—he said, me too.
240.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

241.speaker: The President.
241.text: That is not the kind of leadership that you need, but you should expect that those are promises he's going to keep.
241.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

242.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
242.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

243.speaker: The President.
243.text: And the choice in this election is going to be whose promises are going to be more likely to help you in your life, make sure your kids can go to college, make sure that you are getting a good-paying job, making sure that Medicare and Social Security will be there for you.
243.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

244.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
244.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

245.speaker: Ms. Crowley.
245.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

246.speaker: Economic Concerns/Unemployment Rate
246.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

247.speaker: Gov. Romney.
247.text: I think you know better. I think you know that these last 4 years haven't been so good as the President just described and that you don't feel like you're confident that the next 4 years are going to be much better either. I can tell you that if you were to elect President Obama, you know what you're going to get. You're going to get a repeat of the last 4 years. We just can't afford 4 more years like the last 4 years.
247.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

248.speaker: Gov. Romney.
248.text: He said that by now we'd have unemployment at 5.4 percent. The difference between where it is and 5.4 percent is 9 million Americans without work. I wasn't the one that said 5.4 percent. This was the President's plan; didn't get there.
248.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

249.speaker: Gov. Romney.
249.text: He said he would have by now put forward a plan to reform Medicare and Social Security, because he pointed out they're on the road to bankruptcy. He would reform them. He'd get that done. He hasn't even made a proposal on either one. He said in his first year he'd put out an immigration plan that would deal with our immigration challenges; didn't even file it.
249.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

250.speaker: Gov. Romney.
250.text: This is a President who has not been able to do what he said he'd do. He said that he'd cut in half the deficit. He hasn't done that either; in fact, he doubled it. He said that by now middle income families would have a reduction in their health insurance premiums by $2,500 a year. It's gone up by 2,500 a year. And if Obamacare is passed—or implemented, it's already been passed—if it's implemented fully, it will be another 2,500 on top.
250.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

251.speaker: Gov. Romney.
251.text: The middle class is getting crushed under the policies of a President who has not understood what it takes to get the economy working again. He keeps saying, look, I've created 5 million jobs. That's after losing 5 million jobs. The entire record is such that the unemployment has not been reduced in this country. The unemployment, the number of people who are still looking for work, is still 23 million Americans. There are more people in poverty: one out of six people in poverty.
251.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

252.speaker: Gov. Romney.
252.text: How about food stamps? When he took office, 32 million people were on food stamps. Today, 47 million people are on food stamps. How about the growth of the economy? It's growing more slowly this year than last year and more slowly last year than the year before.
252.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

253.speaker: Gov. Romney.
253.text: The President wants to do well, I understand. But the policies he's put in place, from Obamacare to Dodd-Frank to his tax policies to his regulatory policies, these policies combined have not let this economy take off and grow like it could have. You might say, well, you got an example of when it worked better? Yes. In the Reagan recession, where unemployment hit 10.8 percent, between that period—the end of that recession and the equivalent period of time to today, Ronald Reagan's recovery created twice as many jobs as this President's recovery.
253.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

254.speaker: Gov. Romney.
254.text: Five million jobs doesn't even keep up with our population growth. And the only reason the unemployment rate seems a little lower today is because of all the people that have dropped out of the workforce.
254.title: Barack Obama: Presidential Debate in Hempstead, New York

255.speaker: Gov. Romney.
255.text: The President has tried, but his policies haven't worked. He's great as a speaker and describing his plans and his vision. That's wonderful, except we have a record to look at.
